Award.AwardTitle: Additive Manufacturing of Metal Parts by Electrochemical Deposition

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental research on porosity formation and localization of electrochemical deposition in order to develop an innovative additive process for manufacturing of metal parts without thermal damage. Specifically, the research team will perform molecular dynamics simulation of porosity formation during electrochemical deposition to understand the mechanism of porosity formation in electrochemical deposition, develop a physics-based predictive model for prediction of porosity in electrochemical deposition and conduct experiments to verify the model, test the hypothesis that current density is the determining factor for porosity in electrochemical deposition, evaluate the feasibility of using localized electrochemical deposition to produce functional metal parts from computer aided design models, and establish the process parametric relationships in electrochemical deposition.

This research is expected to have a transformative effect on 3-D printing of a wide variety of conductive materials, result in extensive benefits to biomedical, healthcare, electronic, automotive, and metal working industries, and extend frontiers of additive manufacturing. Research results will provide knowledge and understanding to perform layer-by-layer manufacturing of metal parts by electrochemical deposition and enable producing metal parts by additive manufacturing without thermal damage. This research project features multi-disciplinary approach involving manufacturing technology, molecular dynamics simulation, electrochemistry, control theory, and materials science. This multi-disciplinary approach will positively impact engineering education at University of Cincinnati, and broaden participation of the underrepresented groups in research.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metal parts made by traditional additive manufacturing (AM) processes such as selective laser sintering invariably involve heating the work material (typically powders) and therefore, suffer from thermal damages and residual stress. To overcome these limitations, electrochemical additive Manufacturing (ECAM) – a novel non-thermal metal additive manufacturing process is developed in this project by combining the additive manufacturing concept with the principles of localized electrochemical deposition as illustrated in Figure 1.   

In ECAM, the three-dimensional computer model of the desired part is converted into voxels and necessary tool path is generated. This tool path information is fed to an in-house built AM setup to make the metal parts at room temperature. A video of the metal deposition using the ECAM process (Figure 2) is available on our YouTube channel for the public viewing at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0efMAGZl9XI . 

Physics-based mathematical models have been developed to study the effects of various ECAM process parameters such as applied potential, pulse duty cycle, inter-electrode gap and concentration on the current density and the transient diffusion layer thickness. Models needed to predict the hardness and the yield strength of the deposits have been developed. Some examples of metal structures made by ECAM are shown in Figure 3.

The results of this research are being disseminated through several peer-reviewed publications, presentations at international conferences and in discussions with workshops participants. The ECAM facility at the University of Cincinnati (http://www.min.uc.edu/ucman) so far has attracted more than 300 visitors including K-12 students, teachers, industry persons, collaborators, undergraduate and graduate researchers. This project has resulted in three MS theses, a Ph.D. dissertation, and a provisional US patent.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Metal parts made by traditional additive manufacturing (AM) processes such as selective laser sintering invariably involve heating the work material (typically powders) and therefore, suffer from thermal damages and residual stress. To overcome these limitations, electrochemical additive Manufacturing (ECAM) – a novel non-thermal metal additive manufacturing process is developed in this project by combining the additive manufacturing concept with the principles of localized electrochemical deposition as illustrated in Figure 1. In ECAM, the three-dimensional computer model of the desired part is converted into voxels and necessary tool path is generated. This tool path information is fed to an in-house built AM setup to make the metal parts at room temperature. A video of the metal deposition using the ECAM process (Figure 2) is available on our YouTube channel for the public viewing at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0efMAGZl9XI . Physics-based mathematical models have been developed to study the effects of various ECAM process parameters such as applied potential, pulse duty cycle, inter-electrode gap and concentration on the current density and the transient diffusion layer thickness. Models needed to predict the hardness and the yield strength of the deposits have been developed. Some examples of metal structures made by ECAM are shown in Figure 3. The results of this research are being disseminated through several peer-reviewed publications, presentations at international conferences and in discussions with workshops participants. The ECAM facility at the University of Cincinnati (http://www.min.uc.edu/ucman) so far has attracted more than 300 visitors including K-12 students, teachers, industry persons, collaborators, undergraduate and graduate researchers. This project has resulted in three MS theses, a Ph.D. dissertation, and a provisional US patent. Last Modified: 07/02/2018 Submitted by: Murali Sundaram
